author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I met Nile a few years ago when my boss had a writing session with him at Abbey Road studio 1. I set up a rig to continue editing vocals for a Hot Chip album in one booth, while they worked away self contained in the main control room. 

Nile had been a huge influence on my old band, and Hot Chip had been part of the soundtrack to my college years. Weird working on one on headphones while watching the other grooving away on The Hitmaker through the glass. 

It was a real “this is pretty cool” moment.

author: cian riordan
content: I saw Brian Lucey hitting on the Burl rep. Saw Bainz and Teezio get swarmed by fans. Saw Beckley get a “I saw you on LWMR” moment. Tried to objectively listen to speakers and headphones in a 96dB convention hall (lol). Heavy hang with Will from Neural DSP. Had a great boozy lunch with Kyle, Spider, Wheres-waldo-Tyler, and Beckley. Saw some guitars that bent in half for fitting under airplane seats. There’s an in ear monitor that has 21 drivers now. Finally met Chris Gehringer IRL. Overall, great first NAMM experience. 10/10. Would not go again.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Coincidentally I was exploring a similar idea this morning. I'm on a David Bohm kick and was reading his book 'On Dialogue' and recently finished his 'On Creativity' (would highly recommend both).

In 'On Dialogue' he gives an example I think can be repurposed here. Imagine a song being presented to us. An external signal. When it reaches us it makes contact with what Bohm calls the "whole movement of thought". The thinking and feeling apparatus within us is activated. Thoughts and 'felts' are said to be fundamentally created from memory. Upon contact a 're-presentation' is created where the activity of our thought and feeling reforms the event internally. The 'net presentation' is the fused result. 'Mis-representation' occurs when we mistake the 'net presentation' for the original.

I was thinking on all this and how it might connect to your comment from yesterday, "I told Jon that I don't think he's ever brought more to an album, but also left less of his fingerprints on it".

Bohm brings up Michael Polanyi's idea of tacit knowledge. This is the always running in the background implicit structure we attend to music from, which makes 're-presentation' possible. This includes nostalgia for records we love, perceptual training, bodily memory, tolerance for brightness, etc... Implied here is that this is something you cannot turn off but can cultivate greater awareness off in disciplined participation with art. Polanyi says we attend from subsidiaries to a focal whole. If you start attending to your own sonic fingerprint as the focal object, the structure may collapse. So perhaps Jon was able to integrate a remarkable tacit contribution while being sensitive to the pre-existing structure and coherence of the whole. Maybe coherence and truth have similar meanings here?

Downstream of the artist's origination maybe 'truth' in record making is deep tacit integration, suspending egoic domination, and sensitivity to the internal structure / coherence of the original whole.

author: cian riordan
content: Eventually I caught the hang of things. I started to study the rhythms of the sessions, what order people would file in every morning. I knew the singer liked coffee one way, another guy did something else… I’d start to have that stuff ready. Instead of chumming it up with the band trying to fend off boredom while Eric was mid task, I stuck around on the couch… watching patiently. Those were the moments where he would start looping me into what he was doing, explaining his techniques. Before I knew it, I could start anticipating what he would need next. Someone mentions trying some vocals on a thing? I immediately got going on setting up a mic, getting headphones, even starting to dial in a mix on the headphone box. Percussion? Grab the trunk of junk and start laying out potential options. Once I started actually being useful, I’d be given real tasks. “Hey, do you think you could try doing a preliminary comp of this vocal?” I had been in the room for all the vocal takes, heard the discussion about approach and vibe, even made the singers coffee the right way… why not? That evolved into being trusted with recording stuff in the second studio… we were always running behind, and having me chip away at guitar tracking or re-amping was really useful. Years of this and we were a well oiled machine. I’d get looped into pre-production phone calls and meetings, he would start asking my opinion on things.. drum sounds, microphone choices.

author: cian riordan
content: First time I pulled an all nighter with EV was when he was mixing a Slash live album (Made in Stoke). We had to mix in 5.1 so we had NS10s setup around the console on old tape boxes and had everything up on the console. It was just under 2 hrs of music and we each took an end of the console and were just going at it with Flying Faders... I think thats where I really learned about the power of automation. How much more effective it is just to turn something up or down for a second as opposed to trying to compress/EQ/or saturate your way out of a problem.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
cian's thing is #1 for me. 

beyond that, the basic-but-important things like water, snacks, comfortable places to sit, nice lighting/ vibe, clean, smells good.

also, i get regular feedback on how good the vocals sound in the headphones. when a singer gets on the mic and it's already sounding finished and clear, that's a level of comfort that is beyond everything else listed above. good chain, working headphones, quick options in your template for tune, verb, delay, distortion, etc. be ready for all comers and make it sound amazing from the getgo

author: LAPhill
content: Little PSA here: If at all possible, have backups at your studio of any mission-critical gear. Spare keyboard and mouse, MIDI keyboard, monitor, headphones or speakers, cables, etc. etc... Doesn't have to be as good as your main axe, but something that will do in a pinch. Especially if you don't live close to a Guitar Center/Best Buy that you can run into in an emergency.

author: jantrit
content:
I’m going  fail to properly put this into words but the ability to extrapolate and have an understanding of the learning process/ be driven to take that journey. One example would be this, someone comes in fresh expecting you to spoon feed them the knowledge, that’s not super helpful. But someone comes in and can say, “oh that’s a Patchbay, can you show me how it works”. You can teach those people anything. The desire and hunger to learn on their own and the ability to acquire knowledge for themselves has been a huge divide I’ve noticed in the intern/ college community.  

One time we were setting up a session and I was explaining to our intern my thoughts about which headphones we’d give to each station. (This pair has better bass, we’ll give them to the bass player. These are open back we’ll give them to the horn section so they can blend better) The very next session without having to mention it, she had placed the same headphones in the same places AND ALSO she then took that info and made a the judgement that we’d give the nicest most comfy pair to the vocalist. That’s what I mean about extrapolation.

author: cian riordan
content: I go back and forth. I finally got a decent turntable setup in the studio… calibrated, aligned, etc… and it was very interesting listening to analog and digital back to back. Most records I prefer the clarity and depth of digital, but there were a few (mostly from the 80s) where the analog pressing surpassed the digital. I still think the medium is a net positive in terms of music enjoyment and the collective industry, but I’ve moved beyond touting it as some sort of superior listening format. It’s just not. I remember mastering several records with Doug Sax and he would always joke with me saying, “you know there’s a better medium, right? Sounds better, is cheaper, etc”. Despite being the master, he understood how it’s evolved and had a sense of humor about it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I honestly think you should sit with great headphones and listen to the album front to back. Try and absorb it like a complete art project with your full attention. He has spoken about deliberately creating something that you can't quite grab onto immediately, an album that exists in a liminal space between contemporary and vintage, between lofi and hi res, between genres.

If you sit with the album and listen with the understanding that everything you hear and experience is a choice from a single artist (rather than the multitude of collaborators for most contemporary albums), I think you can enjoy it a lot.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I embrace the occasional lack of focus. I don't necessarily have to work a long full day to stay on track. I do have to stay sufficiently attuned to when I'm in the zone to do my best work. And then a few hours of hard work in that zone is often more productive than many hours of my B+ game. I let my mind wander when it wanders. I go for walks, or watch Netflix, or read. And then when I know I can do good work, I buckle down and do it. If I was ever missing deadlines, I'd recalibrate. But I'm not, so I don't.

author: Rob Domos
content:
So I enjoyed how they sounded but started getting migraines regularly which had never been a problem in my life before. I looked into whether there was any data showing that increased emf exposure near the head was correlated to increase in migraines and it turns out there is data on this and there is a correlation. I took 2 days off from the maxes and the migraines subsided completely. 

Maybe strapping a small computer to one’s brain 9 hours a day is a bit much? I’d still use them for short bursts but will use dumber headphones 99% of the time

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: JakeTB
content: Transient, memorable experiences that get them excited about creating is what generates interest and learning. Get them messing around in a DAW, hearing their own voice through crazy effects, and creating something they can show their friends. Anything deeper than microphone->interface->computer->headphones/speakers is going to to get completely tuned out in the beginning of a program like that. Once they’re excited, they’ll dive deeper themselves.

author: Slow Hand
content: @Dodgy One reason for the specific listening levels that are being mentioned are because of what are called Fletcher-Munson Curves. The gist of it is that we (humans) hear a balance of frequencies differently depending on how loud or how soft the sound is. This affects our ability to accurately judge what the actual balance of a record's frequencies are and make good decisions about a mix. These researchers (Fletcher and Munson) did a lot of research and came up with a chart that shows how our perception of sound changes depending on how loud a sound is. The general takeaway from looking at these results is that we perceive sound as closest to neutral/flat when listening around 80dB and thus it is the least compromised level to listen at.

author: peterlabberton
content: Personally, I don't really bother taking these kinds of notes while tracking. If I'm producing something myself, I prefer to just keep moving and try something, then move on as quickly as possible. If it needs to be redone for some reason, I'll just cook up a sound again and not get too hung up on whether it's identical or not—chances are if we're revisiting it, things could be improved anyway. If I'm engineering for someone else, I'll defer to them, but these are usually situations where things are even *more* time-sensitive (i.e. we're renting an expensive studio), and the situation is very unlikely to be recreated anyway. I was very lucky to have subbed in for @cian riordan with St. Vincent for a couple months in the early stages of this new record—nothing was documented (unless I grabbed a quick photo to cover my own ass), it was all just trying stuff, and if it worked it worked, if not, move on and forget it! Mixing is another story—in the (increasingly) rare instance when I'm mixing on a console, I'll figure out some way of recalling for that particular project. This is usually more or less @Rollmottle's method, except I go even more jank-ass and just scribble song names on a post-it and hold it in front of a piece of gear like a mugshot. Anything on the console is either stored in the console automation, or, like the most recent project I mixed on a console, I'll just calibrate all the faders and run stuff through it, but really *mix* in Pro Tools still. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: cian riordan
content: This was the nice thing about using NS10s as my main monitor... almost all studios had them and with the lack of low end, they don't interact too much with the room so I could at least shape midrange on them.

author: ALXCPH
content: I can only agree with what’s been said. I did the same last time I was on tour. Also sometimes simpler = better. 100 elements might work nicely in your favourite headphones but with a live system. Usually only the necessities and maby a few ear candy stuff is enough. You don’t really need 13 different synths playing the same part! Also if you are playing and inside venue that has a little bit of size to it, you don’t need as much reverb, cuz it happens naturally. If you don’t know what sound system they are running or have any contact to the sound guy, just make sure it at least sounds somewhat good in mono, just to be safe. Also make sure the backing tracks have “room” for the live instrumentalist! That way the sound guy can turn it up without drowning out the band. 🙂

author: Zakhiggins
content:
What mastering really is, is someone with far more experience and reps than you in a highly calibrated room making sure your mix is definitely finished. If you’re just starting out, you probably don’t need it. If you’re looking for that last 5-10%, you probably do. Sometimes they don’t need to do anything other than tell you it’s done (which in my opinion is worth it) and sometimes they have to be more heavy handed. What they actually do (if they’re good) will likely be different every time. It’s about getting the song over the line, and whatever it takes to do that.
You can get plenty of great mastering engineers for 100 dollars or less. Reach out to some peeps on this discord and they’d be happy to help I’m sure

author: Will Pragnell
content: They're probably as good as the best closed back headphones I've used, but I still prefer open backed headphones when I'm at home or somewhere quiet

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Headphones are necessarily very personal, much more so than speakers.

But I've heard most of the focals and all of the Audeze and choose Maxes over all of them. Never heard the Neumanns

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Do you mean that headphones lack feel, so it’s difficult to get the emotion in the work while mixing? I think it’s a different kind of feel. I’ll look for the chest/bass check when listening on speakers but I want to be transported by the atmosphere and connection when listening on headphones. Some of the most formative experiences for me were listening via headphones and I try and remember those fomative feelings when checking on headphones - cassette dubs of Fabio and Grooverider on radio 1 back in the day, Spike’s mixes of Massive Attack and Mad Professor versions, my dad’s vinyl of Dark Side of the Moon etc etc

author: Adam Thein
content:
Found this

“I took the head off a snare drum and started whacking it with a wooden ruler, recording it through a Shure 57 microphone,” he says. “As I did that, I started twisting the hell out of the [API 550] EQ around 1 kHz on it, to the point where it was starting to sound more like a crash. I blended that with a snare I found in the Linn itself, which was a 12-bit machine, so it sounded pretty edgy to start with.” But the coup de grace for the sound was when Z pumped the processed and blended sample through an Auratone speaker set upside down atop another snare drum, which rattled the metal snares and gave the result some ambience and even more high end. The whole thing was limited slightly and then sent to a track on a roll of Ampex 456 running on a Studer A800 at 15 ips. Only a slight amount of reverb was added to the track later on.

author: Berlin

author: Eric Martin
content:
late to this, but if your room is small 78db is gonna be better because the room can’t handle more. There are calibration standards out there AES support a a few and it would be wise to learn them, they all correlate to the meter reading on a db meter = a reading on the meters in the DAW.

Make 78db c weighted = -12db and you will have a loud dynamic pop mix that gets you enough headroom for the mastering engineer.

author: Slow Hand
content: I wonder what the end goal for Apple is. I've got so many questions: Why is it important for Apple Music to support spatial audio? What does spatial audio within headphones do that stereo cannot? Does Dolby Atmos fold down to their spatial audio algorithm in a satisfying way? How many records are actually gonna be mixed for Atmos?

author: Slow Hand
content: I could see spatial audio being good for video games, but I guess I don't yet understand what it offers that you can't already do with stereo headphones and the listener's HRTF.

author: Slow Hand
content: I agree. Atmos is such a high barrier to entry that it's unlikely to be any kind of standard outside of movie theaters and audio obsessives. For that reason I feel like Apple are more interested in the benefits that it must bring to their headphone experience. At least two of their Airpod models already support it. I just don't see the benefit yet.

author: Josh Bowman
content: Have you guys tried spacial audio with the AirPod pros on the Apple TV app from the phone (the only place it works right now)? I thought the headphones weren’t on and the sound was coming out of my phone in the room the first time I tried it. Sounds crazy (pretty neat!). Not sure if it would make music more enjoyable but it seems Serban and Jon hanes have already been doing atmos versions of some of their major label releases for a while now… curious to see how it translates! I saw Josh gudwin built an atmos room too, and Greg wells was talking about it… so seems it’s already happened. I’d imagine the budget is higher/extra on those versions for the mix?

content: WeTransfer, I send via gmail sometimes if that’s easy for the client, some of my clients are evaluating on shit headphones and Bluetooth speakers so I’m not crazy worried about the quality of data compression when they’re listening on those types of speakers

content:
Interesting, I did MP3 on Dropbox until the quality dropped, switched to WAV and it comparable to when I used to do MP3.

The only reason I send WAV before final payment is because the stream quality is so bad and I have no idea how they’re going to listen to the audio. Lots of them listen on phones or headphones straight from Dropbox app.

author: karlemilhald
content: Hey everyone. What are Your impressions on the Dolby Atmos-spacial/headphone version on Apple Music? The mixes obviously vary in quality, but two main problems I notice in all the songs I've heard are 1) A roomy/chourusy sound, which is not a creative choise, but rather seems like an algorithm, which ruins 'in your face vocals' imh. 2) Missing the glue. - These songs may sound amazing on speakers, but from a consumer standpoint, I believe that the binaural Atmos for headphones is gonna be the way 99.9 people are gonna listen. Thoughts??

author: David Fuller
content: surround in headphones is always going to be a bit of a mess

author: David Fuller
content: it relies on spatial cues which, spoiler, headphones can't do

author: karlemilhald
content: Exactly. There are a lot of songs that have a lot of problems. Bob Marley - Is This Love sounds beautiful to me, but that seems to be an exception (and it still gets at bit of that washy sound). i would imagine these mixes are mixed for a proper Atmos setup, but how many of people listening are really gonna have that? I believe in the Atmos format for headphones for that reason. But i think it would require mixing engineers to mix with headphones in mind if that washy/roomy sound should disappear

author: XLII
content: Hi everyone, I'm new to this server, I'm a producer / artist based in Tokyo. Might be a weird question to ask, but I'm wondering if there's anybody here that's basically gotten rid of their studio in favour of working portably >> laptop + headphones or similar and had better results working that way. The reason I'm asking is because I have a nice studio in central Tokyo, but somehow seem to struggle getting in the flow there as opposed to cafes or other studios. Any nomad producers engineers in the house?

author: XLII
content: Thank you! @oaklandmatt Would be super interested to hear your experience and what setup / headphones you work on etc.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
it's great to be mobile and move everywhere. i do keep my vintage 87 with me at all times, so i have a solid vocal chain anywhere (apollo x preamp is more than good enough with the 87). the challenge is headphones, and i haven't found a solution that replaces speakers. i've tried some different open back headphones (grados, focal clear mg) but they don't have the "oomph" that i get from speakers. the imaging and clarity is better than my ath m50x headphones i always have, but the lack of big bass and the annoyance of open back (can't really use in public, on planes, etc) make them not really useful to me.

other than that i have a new M1 mac and can run full ableton and pro tools sessions simultaneously no problem. i can fit an apollo twin x and all the necessary cables, external keyboard, trackball, etc in a backpack. works great

author: XLII
content: Great, yeah, that sounds very similar to the setup I'm thinking of. I use RME in the studio and have an 87 paired with an avalon preamp that I enjoy the sound of, but thought buying an Apollo would be a great portable compromise, cos I hear they have passable pres. That combined with either LCD-X or Focal Clear MG Pro for quiet environments and HD25 for everything else. I'm a huge fan of portability and minimalism, so although I have quite a bit of gear in the studio, it's all powered by 1 MBP, 1 iLok and 1 SSD. Which is always with me.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: Is there another set of speakers or headphones to check if the issue is consistent there? It kinda sounds like a bad tweeter with it only being in one speaker. Also possible check any patches/cables going from monitor section to the speakers. If you flip the L and R pans of the master bus does the issue stay in the same speaker or pan?

author: cian riordan
content: Swap dem NS10's L/R. (Edit: erg, maybe not. They're so high up. I've found them to sound better with the tweeter hi, rather than low. Most people who have the upright versions, and try to use them horizontally, forget to swap sides)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I can revise, QC etc on headphones but almost impossible to do a new master on headphones. Sadly

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Too much to get into but I’ve hinted at all the components here before and pointed to research too. Right now we have all the headphone companies focussed on just one aspect of the experience, driver design. Imagine 10 car companies all making better and better engines but no one ever thinks to upgrade the transmissions, brakes, wheels etc

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
Mostly folks working with headphones.com (Blaine Lacrosse, Griffin Silver) but a couple of them have designed their own headphones. DMS and Auribus Acoustics mainly. They’re really into both the research side of things and the “how does all of this work together to make something that sounds good”
The research they’ve been getting into has been helping to chart a good way forward. Especially now with preference bounds around a target rather than strict adherence to it since everyone’s head and preferences are different.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Tuning a headphone is more than altering the driver and any EQ, it’s the whole housing/cup as well

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But you can’t mix or master at a high level on headphones reliably

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Yeah I’m not big into mixing on headphones but have been interested in the developments just in case

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m as convinced as I was 5 years ago that we’ll mostly be mixing on $5k to $10k headphones in a decade

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: VSX seems weird to me because it’s a closed back system and that’s inherently seal-dependent (among other problems with most closed back headphones)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Instead of me saying no no no, ask yourself *why don’t headphones translate today?* and what would be the total addressable market if they did?

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Glenn Schick is doing it solely on headphones apparently, I always thought he was an outlier and I know he still does big records although I can't vouch for the sonics of them

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
The only thing anyone ever notes about Glenn is that he works on headphones

His work may be great but in the thousands of times I’ve gone “wow that sounds great” and checked the tidal credits it’s never once led to his name. Randy, Chris, Ted, Athens etc many times over

(But again as I always say he could I’m sure legitimately say the same thing about me. So I’m not trying to project status, just observing that he’s often held up as an example of why we *can* work on headphones but no one seems to know his actual work)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ve mastered plenty of work done in headphones and it can be fine, the more synthetic the genre the easier it is to do. But vocal placement, low end relationships, imaging always feel less than 100%

author: Nick Stetina
content: Gonna have to add Meze Elite’s to “try” list if Dan Clark’s are in the running. Headphones are super personal, as you suggested, but it feels like I’ve tried them all and Meze isn’t involved in the conversation enough, imo.

author: Nick Stetina
content: Headphones seem even more divisive than speakers though. One man’s dog shit is another’s end game. I’ve read some mastering engineer’s who adore the HEDDphone, but for me, I’ve never returned a pair so quickly 😬

author: spectrummasters
content: I just spent a month abroad prepping / basic balancing /eqing mixes on earbuds . I forbade myself from doing anything to the low end at all until I got back to my speakers . It worked out well . I’m v happy with the headphone decisions . However , I judge my low end  entirely by feel in the room though , the physical stimulation I feel guides me . A while back we discussed here in reference to a podcast I believe  ruairi posted , about using feel in mixing . I’m interested if anyone here has a particular vision about how one can compensate for or say goodbye to that specific aspect of sound (the feel ) and how useful it is in record making . I think of drums and bass particularly in terms of the frequency ranges and how the transients feel on my ears / chest / belly etc for the different parts. Any vision on how headphones mixing : mastering can satisfy this

author: spectrummasters
content:
What great work you referenced there , I fully agree about fab and groove on headphones . That was me at uni lol ! I’m with you . 

I think what I’m wondering about is …..with our modern lifestyles I totally get how the consumer is listening mostly by headphones now . And we as music makers are freed up enormously by working in headphones . I think rod waves album got a Grammy and was mixed on headphones iirc, perhaps it was a number 1 . Anyhoo , so I’m not contesting the movement to headphone mixing , I’m wondering for those who intend to or are doing all their work on headphones …..how will you know how it feels in air ? As one day , the artist will perform it live . I come from club and sound system culture , so the ultimate destination is a wall of speaker boxes …..and in the end music has to be re inforced for public performance . How do we know we ve got that balance right if we don’t use speakers ? (Honest question )

author: samvalentine
content:
Hey, I’m not sure where to post this exactly, but I had an interesting experience the other day that I’d like to share with the group and hopefully get some perspective on.

I was touching up a track with a producer friend at the end of a writing session. Vocals and guitar recorded over a 2track beat. I typically throw a Waves L2 on my master, just to bring up the level for the rough bounce, never doing much more than a dB or two of gain reduction. In this case I had the threshold of the L2 set at -3.4. The producer said try -3.5, then back to -3.4, then -3.5… flipping back and forth seeing what he liked more. I couldn’t hear a difference. (I should say that we weren’t in a well treated room, working on some mid sized genelecs. It’s a  setup neither of us is super familiar with.) He decided -3.4 was better and I was in disbelief that he could even hear a difference. I asked if I could do a blind test to see if he could tell which setting was which. He closed his eyes and I switched back and forth a bunch of times before landing on a setting, and he called it correct three times in a row. He said he could hear something in the kick drum but couldn’t explain more than that.
I need a sanity check. I know my ears aren’t hall of fame, but I’m still in disbelief that he was able to tell a .1dB difference in volume on the limiter.

author: David Fuller
content: Fwiw for me with speakers I found it very enlightening to go and listen to a ton; I'm at the point with my ears that I was able to pick out whether or not speakers worked for me in about 5 minutes of reference listening. But I've also suddenly been doing audio for 16 years and I've stepped on a ton of auditory rakes in that time (two sets of Focals, a set of Adams, and a set of Barefoots), so I know what does and doesn't work for me

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: if possible, when using the VME stuff do it on the same pair of headphones you were measured on

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But what I’ve seen for stereo is that they are using IR impulses to measure your room with mics in your ear, then measuring again with their headphones, and using convolution (using loosely) to match

author: andrew_yv
content:
Sony set me up with it for Mike’s BH room in both stereo and atmos. It’s the first spatialization tech that has impressed me. Not sure how quickly I would reach for it in stereo, but I can confidently pre-mix things in atmos with it, and with some loss of detail, it really does sound like *those speakers in that room through my ears*

Process is pretty cool and elegant. They put electret mics in your ears, record IR sweeps of each speaker in your room through them, then put headphones on, record IR sweeps of those, then have some sort of sum/difference algo that translates it all.

When you get measured, go for relatively high SPL sweeps. We tried it at a few different levels and at lower levels, the result was pretty unimpressive. You can also go too high and distort, but worth trying a couple times if they’re game, which I’m 100% sure they will be for you

author: cian riordan
content: Foamies all the way here. I've just gotten used to how they sound over 20+ years of wearing them playing & listening to music. Like a good set of studio monitors -- you gotta acclimate to them.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Anything too deep into ‘audiophile’ territory feels most useful as fun fact research, rather than part of making music, for me.

When I was a kid I LIVED my music to get through hard times, listening to great artists on shitty headphones and cassettes - In that vein, I believe the energy of the creation trumps whatever sonic difference DAWs have, meaning whatever allows the creator to tap into that inspiration is what’s most important in the end, and my DAWs are best for me simply cus they remove points of friction in how my brain goes through its creative process.
